title: How to Remake Cool Soap

steps.headline: Buy three or more bars of unscented soap from a dollar store.
steps.description: Make sure you have one or two bars of colored scented soap as well. Keep in mind that you will need to have a fragrance oil that will smell good with the soap.

steps.headline: Using a grater, carefully grate the unscented bars of soap.
steps.description: Set a bowl underneath your grater so that it will catch the shavings. Make sure not to spill.

steps.headline: Using a knife, carefully cut up the colored soap into pieces.
steps.description: The size and number of the pieces doesn't matter.

steps.headline: Using a plastic or metal mold, add some colored soap at the bottom.
steps.description: Remember to leave enough soap for later!

steps.headline: Get a double boiler.
steps.description: Fill the bottom part of the boiler halfway up with water.

steps.headline: Pour your grated, unscented soap into the top part of the boiler.
steps.description: Then, turn your stove to high.

steps.headline: As the water boils, consistently mix your unscented soap, then add one tablespoon of olive oil.
steps.description: As you're mixing, add as much colored soap and fragrance as you desire. The olive oil will soften your skin.

steps.headline: Melt the soap only until it is clumpy.
steps.description: Beware of melting it for too long! Once you see that the soap is getting clumpy, turn the stove off.

steps.headline: Wait until the soap has cooled off a bit before using a plastic glove to place the soap into the mold.
steps.description: Firmly press it down. A little bit of the colored soap that you added earlier should be located in the bottom of the mold. You should not have melted all the colored soap.

steps.headline: Wait for a few minutes until the soap is cool, then completely wrap it and the mold with plastic wrap.
Let the soap harden in the mold.
steps.description: This may take a few hours. Once it has hardened, gently pop it out of the mold. If you're giving this away as a gift, place the soap in a box (a tin box is recommended) with a label announcing what it is inside the box. Wrap it nicely.

text: Buy three or more bars of unscented soap from a dollar store. Make sure you have one or two bars of colored scented soap as well. Keep in mind that you will need to have a fragrance oil that will smell good with the soap. Using a grater, carefully grate the unscented bars of soap. Set a bowl underneath your grater so that it will catch the shavings. Make sure not to spill. Using a knife, carefully cut up the colored soap into pieces. The size and number of the pieces doesn't matter. Using a plastic or metal mold, add some colored soap at the bottom. Remember to leave enough soap for later! Get a double boiler. Fill the bottom part of the boiler halfway up with water. Pour your grated, unscented soap into the top part of the boiler. Then, turn your stove to high. As the water boils, consistently mix your unscented soap, then add one tablespoon of olive oil. As you're mixing, add as much colored soap and fragrance as you desire. The olive oil will soften your skin. Melt the soap only until it is clumpy. Beware of melting it for too long! Once you see that the soap is getting clumpy, turn the stove off. Wait until the soap has cooled off a bit before using a plastic glove to place the soap into the mold. Firmly press it down. A little bit of the colored soap that you added earlier should be located in the bottom of the mold. You should not have melted all the colored soap. Wait for a few minutes until the soap is cool, then completely wrap it and the mold with plastic wrap.  Let the soap harden in the mold. This may take a few hours. Once it has hardened, gently pop it out of the mold. If you're giving this away as a gift, place the soap in a box (a tin box is recommended) with a label announcing what it is inside the box. Wrap it nicely. Finished.
